channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Minivans at the Food Pantry: Meet America’s New Needy
item.description: The economic strain of the coronavirus pandemic has more Americans turning to food banks and charity for help feeding their families.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango and Brenda Ann Kenneally

item.title: Efforts to Channel Protests Into More Votes Face Challenges in Kenosha
item.description: Some Black residents of Kenosha, upended by the police shooting of Jacob Blake, weren’t convinced that an election would solve the problem.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: “Let’s say I did go out and vote and I voted for Biden,” said Michael Lindsey, a friend of Mr. Blake’s who protested for several nights after the shooting. “That’s not going to change police brutality.”

item.title: The Portland Protests: What This Teenager Learned
item.description: Last summer was all about dance team and teen parties. But after she watched George Floyd’s death in a video on her phone, Daria Allen’s world drastically changed.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daria Allen is one of many protesters who have rallied nightly for racial justice in downtown Portland, Ore.

item.title: Mississippi Wants Magnolia to Be Centerpiece of New State Flag
item.description: A committee finished its search for a flag to replace the one with a Confederate emblem that had flown for 126 years. It now moves to a statewide ballot.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Rogelio V. Solis/Associated Press
item.media:description: The winning design for the new Mississippi state flag was displayed last month outside the Old Capitol Museum in Jackson, Miss.

item.title: Cleveland Officer Is Shot and Killed
item.description: A second person was also killed, a police union official said. Details were scarce, and the police were still gathering evidence, he said.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Yu

item.title: Trump Angrily Denies Report He Called Fallen Soldiers ‘Losers’ and ‘Suckers’
item.description: The report, in The Atlantic, could be problematic for the president because he is counting on strong support among the military for his re-election bid.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Francois Mori/Associated Press
item.media:description: John F. Kelly, left, the White House chief of staff at the time, and Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the time, attending a ceremony at the Aisne-Marne American Cemetery in France in November 2018, after President Trump declined to appear.

item.title: This Labor Day, These Workers Are Trying to Staying Afloat
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has brought various hardships. An artist, bookseller, comedian and five others share their stories of how they are coping with all the uncertainty.
item.category: Eso Won Books (Los Angeles, Calif, Retailer)
Stand Up NY (Manhattan, NY, Comedy Club)
Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Maridelis Morales Rosado for The New York Times
item.media:description: “April was dark”: On the rooftop of Baseera Khan’s apartment building in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The artist not only suffered from the coronavirus, but also struggled financially after exhibitions were put on hold and teaching gigs evaporated.

item.title: Louisiana Man Faces Murder Charge in Fatal Shooting of a Panhandler
item.description: A Black victim’s family seeks a federal investigation into how the police have handled a shooting after a confrontation with a white man.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Michael Forest Reinoehl, Suspect in Portland Shooting, Is Killed by Officers
item.description: Law enforcement agents killed Michael Forest Reinoehl while trying to arrest him, four officials said. He was being investigated in the fatal shooting of a supporter of a far-right group.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Golden, Mike Baker and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Joshua Bessex for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Reinoehl was killed by a federally led fugitive task force in Lacey, Wash., on Thursday. He was being investigated in a fatal shooting at a Portland protest.

item.title: As Others Condemn Putin Critic’s Poisoning, Trump Just Wants to ‘Get Along’
item.description: At a rally on Thursday, President Trump did not mention the dissident Aleksei A. Navalny, or warnings that Moscow is trying to interfere with the election. When news reports mention Russia, he said, “I just turn it off.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If I get along with Russia, is that a good thing or bad thing?” President Trump asked the crowd at a rally on Thursday in Latrobe, Pa. “I think it’s a good thing.”

item.title: University Investigates Claim That White Professor Pretended to Be Black
item.description: George Washington University said it was looking into a blog post written under the name of Jessica A. Krug detailing a long history of deception about her racial identity.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson and Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Mary F. Calvert for The New York Times
item.media:description: A history professor at George Washington University revealed in a blog post to claiming a Black identity, which was not her identity at birth.

item.title: Netanyahu Privately Condoned U.S. Plan to Sell Arms to U.A.E., Officials Say
item.description: The package being pushed by the Trump White House — which could shift the military balance in the Middle East — includes an electronic warfare plane, the EA-18G Growler.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong and Michael LaForgia
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Tal Shahar
item.media:description: President Trump’s announcement of a diplomatic breakthrough between Israel and the United Arab Emirates came as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was trying to manage multiple crises.

item.title: Biden, in Kenosha, Makes Case for Healing and Unity, Not Division
item.description: Two days after President Trump traveled to Wisconsin to focus attention on violence and disorder, Joe Biden sought to strike a drastically different tone, repudiating the president’s divisive approach to matters of racial injustice.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. held a community event at Grace Lutheran Church in Kenosha, Wis., on Thursday.

item.title: Student Charged in Cyberattacks at Miami-Dade Schools
item.description: Virtual classes in the fourth-largest school district in the United States were choked by glitches this week. A 16-year-old high school junior has admitted to the cyberattacks.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Cristobal Herrera-Ulashkevich/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The police believe that more people may have been involved in cyberattacks at the Miami-Dade schools this week.

item.title: Transgender People Face New Legal Fight After Supreme Court Victory
item.description: Though the Supreme Court embraced a broad definition of sex in June, the Department of Health and Human Services pressed ahead with changes that narrowed the definition of sex in the Affordable Care Act.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cecilia Gentili, left, and Tanya Walker in Manhattan in August.

item.title: Buffy Wicks Voted on the Floor With a Newborn in Her Arms
item.description: The California state assemblywoman brought her month-old baby to the chamber — and instantly became an image of moms who do it all.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: California State Assembly, via Associated Press

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Lies Ahead
item.description: Will the virus resurge with a vengeance?
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Irving Kanarek, Lawyer Who Defended Charles Manson, Dies at 100
item.description: The national spotlight that focused on Mr. Kanarek made his disruptive circus of courtroom tactics almost as fascinating as his bizarre clients.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Irving Kanarek, right, in 1970 with Charles Manson, whom he defended in the macabre killings of the actress Sharon Tate and six other people.

item.title: Robert Pattinson Tests Positive for Coronavirus, Halting ‘Batman’ Production
item.description: Work on the film first shut down in March because of the pandemic, which has staggered the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “The Batman,” which had been filming outside London, stars Robert Pattinson.

item.title: Voting Twice? Trump Creates a New Headache for Election Officials
item.description: They say he is sowing confusion about systems that already have robust checks against fraud.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, speaking at a ceremony in Wilmington, N.C., encouraged Americans to try to vote multiple times, which is illegal.

item.title: Justice Dept. Plans to File Antitrust Charges Against Google in Coming Weeks
item.description: The attorney general is said to have set a deadline over the objections of career lawyers who say they need more time to build the case.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr, a former telecom industry executive who argued an antitrust case in front of the Supreme Court, has shown great interest in the Google case.

item.title: The Biden campaign enlists two former players to blame the Trump administration for the lack of Big Ten football.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Leon Halip/Getty Images
item.media:description: Calvin Johnson, the former Detroit Lions wide receiver, in 2014.

item.title: Pinterest reins in advertising related to political terms.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac

item.title: Allies and Former U.S. Officials Fear Trump Could Seek NATO Exit in a Second Term
item.description: President Trump is said to have spoken privately for years about withdrawing from the alliance, a move that critics say would be a major victory for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at an event in Wilmington, N.C., on Wednesday commemorating the 75th anniversary of the end of World War II, a conflict from whose ashes NATO was formed.

item.title: How Trump is Sowing Distrust
item.description: From business competition in New York to President Barack Obama’s birthplace to mail-in voting, President Trump’s goal has been to undermine the opposition and leave people uncertain about what to believe.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump disembarking Air Force One last week at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland. For decades, his goal has been to undermine the opposition.

item.title: Dwayne Johnson, the Rock, Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
item.description: The actor and former wrestler known as the Rock said on Instagram that his entire family had tested positive. “It has nothing to do with politics,” he said. “Wear your mask.”
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.media:credit: Emma Mcintyre/Getty Images
item.media:description: Dwayne Johnson last year during the premiere for his film “Fast & Furious Presents: Hobbs & Shaw.”

item.title: A smooth Massachusetts election could also be a cautionary tale.
item.description: Election experts said that Tuesday’s primary offered a mix of smart policies and harsh deadlines, and that the state benefited from not having a highly charged political atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: More than 760,000 absentee ballots that arrived by mail were prepared, processed and ready to be counted on Election Day in Massachusetts.

item.title: A former top N.R.A. official calls for gun control in a new book.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joshua Powell, the former chief of staff for the National Rifle Association’s executive director, Wayne LaPierre, calls for universal background checks in a new book.

item.title: ‘Is It Even Possible to Play 30 Sports Simultaneously?’
item.description: Thursday: A reporter tries to answer that, and other questions about how things will play out for college athletics.
item.dc:creator: John Branch and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Rather than playing host to games this fall, Memorial Stadium at U.C. Berkeley holds socially distant individual workouts. Each athlete gets a station. Equipment is sanitized between sessions.

item.title: Rick Snyder, a former Michigan governor, is the latest prominent Republican to back Biden.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Al Goldis/Associated Press
item.media:description: Former Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan in 2018. He called Joseph R. Biden Jr. a man with strong moral character and empathy who would bring civility back to a nation that is badly divided.

item.title: A wave of polls taken after the conventions show little change in Biden’s lead.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Chris Creese for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oklahoma Democrats watched the final night of the convention at a drive-in theater in Tulsa last month.

item.title: One Man’s Plea to His City Council: Rename Boneless Wings
item.description: “Nothing about boneless chicken wings actually comes from the wing of a chicken,” he told the Lincoln, Neb., council. “We’ve been living a lie for far too long.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Jenny Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many wing lovers sneer at the boneless variety, which is usually made by deep-frying slices of chicken breast.

item.title: After being used to spread disinformation, Facebook seeks to limit election chaos.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Facebook, bracing for a contentious campaign, said it would ban new political ads in the week before Election Day.

item.title: An internal Census Bureau document lends weight to worries of a hasty 2020 count.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:credit: Christian Monterrosa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers in Perris, Calif., handed out census information last month.

item.title: Homeland Security blocked warnings of a Russian campaign against Biden.
item.description: The department’s leaders declined to publish a memo describing Russian attempts to question Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s health, prompting new scrutiny of political influence at the department.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Amr Alfiky/The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian state media agencies were posting “allegations about the poor mental health” of Joseph R. Biden Jr., a July 9 intelligence bulletin warned.

item.title: Trump moves to cut federal funding from Democratic cities.
item.description: The president directed officials to identify “anarchist jurisdictions” and move to withhold funds as he tries to build his campaign around the unrest that has accompanied racial justice protests.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Jesse McKinley
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “My administration will not allow federal tax dollars to fund cities that allow themselves to deteriorate into lawless zones,” President Trump wrote in a memo.

item.title: As he questions his opponent’s health, Trump finds his own under scrutiny.
item.description: The president denied he had “mini-strokes” at the time of a mysterious trip to the hospital last year. But he raised more questions when he could not keep his explanations for that visit straight.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The question of presidential health has sometimes played an important role in elections, but rarely has it seemed more acute than this year as President Trump, 74, squares off against Joseph R. Biden Jr., 77.

item.title: Facebook Moves to Stop Election Misinformation
item.description: The social network said it would block new political ads in late October, among other measures, to reduce misinformation and interference.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Photographs by Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Facebook is taking steps to minimize misinformation and election confusion as President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. vie for the presidency.

item.title: What All the New Polls Mean for Biden
item.description: The race still has a clear leader, but could be tightening: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: A Smooth Election
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ballot drop-off box in Chelsea, Mass.

item.title: Trump Vaccine Chief Casts Doubt on Coronavirus Vaccine by Election Day
item.description: Just as Thailand reached 100 days without a new local case, it found one. The New York Times surveyed more than 1,500 colleges and found that over two-thirds have reported at least one case.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Its Electric Grid Under Strain, California Turns to Batteries
item.description: When demand exceeded supply in a recent heat wave, electricity stored at businesses and even homes was called into service. With proper management, batteries could have made up for an offline gas plant.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

item.title: N.R.A.’s Former No. 2 Joshua Powell Calls for Gun Control
item.description: A new book from a controversial former executive accuses the National Rifle Association of “appealing to the paranoia and darkest side of our members.”
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Inside the NRA: A Tell-All Account of Corruption, Greed, and Paranoia Within the Most Powerful Political Group in America (Book)
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joshua Powell was chief of staff for the National Rifle Association’s executive director, Wayne LaPierre. In his new book, Mr. Powell calls for universal background checks.

item.title: Why an Eviction Ban Alone Won’t Prevent a Housing Crisis
item.description: Renters receive more relief, but there’s a looming problem for landlords, especially those who own just a few properties.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrating last month in San Francisco for the continuation of a pause on evictions.
